name: Chip
description: Chip is an isometric puzzle game with robots, electricity and fancy dress! The player must help recharge Chip - a plucky little red robot - who has been imprisoned by the nefarious villain, Rust.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: 1.6Ghz Pentium 4 / AMD Athlon II Memory: 512 MB RAM Graphics: Intel Integrated Graphics 4000
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 8.1 Processor: 1.4Ghz Dual Core Intel i3 Memory: 512 MB RAM Graphics: Intel Integrated Graphics 4000

reviews.review_text: Played it for a couple of hours, and could quite happily put a few more into it. Fun game, nice graphics, solid gameplay and challenging puzzles. Over all worth a buy.

It's a cute little puzzle game with a lot of potential, but the horrible controls are a dealbreaker. If one click doesn't respond - what sadly happenes way too often - you can't finish the level in time and have to start over.
Good Game! Not for 'GAMERS'... But definitely good for times when you are bored and in search of an addicting game.

Very fun and very engrossing, perfect for killing a few hours on, now a solid member of my go-to puzzle games :). Some of the lightbulbs can be frustrating to figure out and, while I enjoy that, others may just skip ahead. As with many games of this kind, there's no penalty for that, or for experimentation.

I'm not a fast player, so I would have been hesitant to buy this game because the puzzles are timed, but as I got it for free, I thought it won't matter, if I won't get past the first level. I have now managed to unlock all levels and unlock all but the last one of the wardrobe items.   It's a fun game and it got me totally hooked. Solving the puzzles within the time limit is hard, and it has taken me a lot of tries, giving up on a puzzle and coming back the next day to try again. What really sets this one apart from many other timed puzzle games is that I don't mind trying and trying again until I get there.
Very cute idea and style. You just spent your time shooting electicity on little light buld dude that is sleeping and try to do this in few moves and fast as possible. Good game.

Really enjoyed it. Nice and challenging puzzle game, but the controls can be a bit awful sometimes. It looks like the developers intended to add more levels, because it shows I collected 240/300 light bulbs and I've already cleared everything, but apparently they never got around to do it, so I doubt it's still in the works.

If I played this game on my smartphone, I would love it. But I'm playing on my PC, and this game shouts 'mobile game' from the first second you start it.  Biggest issue I have with Chip is that it often takes more than one click to detect an action, and that can be a problem in a game that requires speed. Do I recommend it? I'm stuck between Yes and No but unfortunately Steam knows only 0 and 1. This is a strictly subjective review. Try it out and see if you like it - on sale it can be bought for under 1€ and you might enjoy it.

Chip is an interesting puzzle game. The concept is solid, and the artwork and usability is spot-on, but the only thing that puts me off about it is how abruptly it ends.  Don't get me wrong - there are enough levels to justify buying the game. My playtime for this game reflects playing through and completing levels, as well as achievements, if you want to gauge how long you'll probably play this.  There is a lot of room for expansion and additions - all the framework is there to build this game up. Unfortunately for the game and the players, the final bonus levels are where the puzzles get very interesting, which would allow for some pretty cool combinations. If it didn't abruptly end. Despite a lack of strong story or narrative (there is a basic story, but it's not an important theme), the game felt like it ended on a cliffhanger.  This is one of the few games in my library that deserved more attention from Steam users than it received, and would be a great addition to your library if you like puzzles.

Controls are finicky, made worse by the fact that the puzzles requires split-second manipulation of objects. Even after having solved the puzzle mentally, it often took 6-10 attempts to actually complete the level because of timing and controls are very unforgiving. I hoped the second set of puzzles that unlocked would have more interesting puzzles, nope, more of the same ridiculously timing-driven object manipulation. It feels less of a puzzle game and more of a finicky 'platformer' having to perfectly jump in or jump out of the path of a moving object.

Chip is a cutesy 3-star-per-level puzzle game, but then again what isn’t? It seems like between these mobile-port style puzzle games, 2D retro platformers and RPGMaker shovelware there is not much else releasing regularly on Steam. Chip works just fine, it has some cool twists in mechanics and has a nice amount of difficulty in later levels. However, this sentiment could be copy/pasted for just about any of these puzzle games and it really doesn’t do anything special to stand out from the crowd. If you enjoy these kinds of games, Chip works, but it’s really nothing I would recommend to a friend.
